channel.title: Amazing Podcast Episodes: ~3x curated episodes per week
channel.description: Curating & reposting the ~3 best podcasts per week. There are simply too many good podcasts out there, let us pick the best two each week for you. Copyright is owned by the publisher, not this podcast, audio is streamed directly from publisher's servers.
channel.itunes:subtitle: ~3x curated episodes per week
channel.itunes:author: Amazing Podcasts
channel.itunes:summary: Curating & reposting the ~3 best podcasts per week. There are simply too many good podcasts out there, let us pick the best two each week for you. Copyright is owned by the publisher, not this podcast, audio is streamed directly from publisher's servers.

itunes:owner.itunes:name: Amazing Podcast Episodes: ~3x curated episodes per week

item.title: Exponential Wisdom: Living Long Enough to Live Forever
item.description: Peter talks about Ray Kurzweil’s belief that children born today will have the ability to have an indefinite lifespan. Dan describes his thoughts on attitude and why the future is something you must work toward. Peter puts into perspective the amazing times we are living in, citing how the human lifespan has doubled over the last century.
item.itunes:author: TPeter Diamandis and Dan Sullivan
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter talks about Ray Kurzweil’s belief that children born today will have the ability to have an indefinite lifespan. Dan describes his thoughts on attitude and why the future is something you must work toward. Peter puts into perspective the amazing times we are living in, citing how the human lifespan has doubled over the last century.

Dan describes his thoughts on attitude and why the future is something you must work toward. Peter puts into perspective the amazing times we are living in, citing how the human lifespan has doubled over the last century.

item.title: The Tim Ferriss Show: My Life Extension Pilgrimage to Easter Island
item.description: This episode was a blast. It was a tropical exploration of biology, life extension, and all good things. This included a lot of Carmenere wine and good old-fashioned ball busting.
item.itunes:author: Tim Ferriss: Bestselling Author, Human Guinea Pig
item.itunes:subtitle: This episode was a blast. It was a tropical exploration of biology, life extension, and all good things. This included a lot of Carmenere wine and good old-fashioned ball busting.
item.itunes:summary: This episode was a blast. It was a tropical exploration of biology, life extension, and all good things. This included a lot of Carmenere wine and good old-fashioned ball busting.

item.title: Exponent: Facebook - Sins of Commission and Omission
item.description: Ben and James discuss the fake news epidemic on Facebook, from its structural causes to its effects. Then, Facebook committed sins of omission; the tech industry ought not do the same.
item.itunes:author: Ben Thompson / James Allworth
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben and James discuss the fake news epidemic on Facebook, from its structural causes to its effects. Then, Facebook committed sins of omission; the tech industry ought not do the same.
item.itunes:summary: Ben and James discuss the fake news epidemic on Facebook, from its structural causes to its effects. Then, Facebook committed sins of omission; the tech industry ought not do the same.

item.title: POLITICO's Off Message: Best of Off Message
item.description: In honor of Election Day, Glenn Thrush takes a look back at his favorite moments on the show - interviews that framed the narrative, made news, gave insight into the candidates' mindsets or, at least, gave us a laugh.
item.itunes:author: POLITICO
item.itunes:subtitle: In honor of Election Day, Glenn Thrush takes a look back at his favorite moments on the show - interviews that framed the narrative, made news, gave insight into the candidates' mindsets or, at least, gave us a laugh.
item.itunes:summary: In honor of Election Day, Glenn Thrush takes a look back at his favorite moments on the show - interviews that framed the narrative, made news, gave insight into the candidates' mindsets or, at least, gave us a laugh.

item.title: Freakonomics Radio: How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: The U.S. president is often called the "leader of free world." But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studiosy
item.itunes:subtitle: The U.S. president is often called the "leader of free world." We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.

item.title: The Minefiled: What is the meaning of ‘Trump’?
item.description: The United States became a different nation on 8 November, with the election of Donald Trump, than it was the day before.
item.itunes:author: ABC Radio National
item.itunes:subtitle: The United States became a different nation on 8 November, with the election of Donald Trump, than it was the day before.
item.itunes:summary: The United States became a different nation on 8 November, with the election of Donald Trump, than it was the day before.

item.title: This American Life: Master of Her Domain… Name
item.description: A story about Hillary Clinton that offers a different picture than what we’ve been hearing from both sides during this campaign. And some funny stuff, because everyone’s tired of the election.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: A story about Hillary Clinton that offers a different picture than what we’ve been hearing from both sides during this campaign. And some funny stuff, because everyone’s tired of the election.

item.title: Freakonomics Radio: Why Are We Still Using Cash?
item.description: It facilitates crime, bribery, and tax evasion -- and yet some governments (including ours) are printing more cash than ever. Other countries, meanwhile, are ditching cash entirely. And if Star Trek is right, we won't have money of any sort in the 24th century.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studiosy
item.itunes:subtitle: It facilitates crime, bribery, and tax evasion -- and yet some governments (including ours) are printing more cash than ever. Other countries, meanwhile, are ditching cash entirely. And if Star Trek is right, we won't have money of any sort in the 24th century.

item.title: Hidden Brain: Give Me Your Tired...
item.description: Our airwaves are filled with debates about migrants, refugees, and undocumented immigrants... Who should be in the United States, who shouldn't, and who should decide?
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:subtitle: Our airwaves are filled with debates about migrants, refugees, and undocumented immigrants... Who should be in the United States, who shouldn't, and who should decide?
item.itunes:summary: Our airwaves are filled with debates about migrants, refugees, and undocumented immigrants... Who should be in the United States, who shouldn't, and who should decide?

item.title: Freakonomics Radio: This Is Your Brain on Podcasts
item.description: Neuroscientists still have a great deal to learn about the human brain. One recent MRI study sheds some light, finding that a certain kind of storytelling stimulates enormous activity across broad swaths of the brain. The takeaway is obvious: you should be listening to even more podcasts.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studiosy

item.title: The Ezra Klein Show: Francis Fukuyama on whether America's democracy is decaying
item.description: Francis Fukuyama is a political scientist, a public intellectual, and progenitor of the famed "End of History" thesis. But his recent work is his most important yet.
item.itunes:author: Vox / Panoply
item.itunes:subtitle: Francis Fukuyama is a political scientist, a public intellectual, and progenitor of the famed "End of History" thesis. But his recent work is his most important yet.

item.title: On Being: Alain de Botton — A School of Life for Atheists
item.description: Alain de Botton is a philosopher who likes the best of religion, but doesn’t believe in God. He says that the most boring question you can ask of any religion is whether it is true.
item.itunes:author: On Being with Krista Tippett
item.itunes:subtitle: Alain de Botton is a philosopher who likes the best of religion, but doesn’t believe in God. He says that the most boring question you can ask of any religion is whether it is true.

item.title: TED Radio Hour: Anthropocene
item.description: Some scientists say we're in a new geological age where humans are having an unprecedented impact on Earth. This hour, TED speakers ask what this means for the future of our planet, and our species.
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:subtitle: Some scientists say we're in a new geological age where humans are having an unprecedented impact on Earth. This hour, TED speakers ask what this means for the future of our planet, and our species.

item.title: Dumbo Feather: Hugh Mackay: Social researcher, kindness advocate
item.description: Hugh Mackay has been examining how we live for six decades. So he's got some pretty great insights into what makes a good life. We loved our chat with him!
item.itunes:author: Conversations with extraordinary people
item.itunes:subtitle: Hugh Mackay has been examining how we live for six decades. So he's got some pretty great insights into what makes a good life. We loved our chat with him!

item.title: This American Life: #560: Abdi and the Golden Ticket
item.description: A story about someone who's desperately trying – against long odds – to make it to the United States and become an American. Abdi is a Somali refugee living in Kenya and gets the luckiest break of his life: he wins a lottery that puts him on a short list for a U.S. visa. This is his ticket out. But before he can cash in his golden ticket, the police start raiding his neighborhood, targeting refugees.
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.itunes:subtitle: A story about someone who's desperately trying – against long odds – to make it to the United States and become an American. item.title: The Tim Ferriss Show: The Art and Science of Learning Anything Faster
item.description: This is a special episode because it doesn't focus on the lessons of one particular person. Instead, I explore the tips, tricks, and framework I've used to learn just about any skill.
item.itunes:author: Tim Ferriss: Bestselling Author, Human Guinea Pig

item.description: Technology companies have become a powerful way to build the future. Our goal with this series is to share advice about how you can do it, too.

item.title: Dear Sugar: Totally Confused' Finds A Resolution
item.description: The Sugars get an update from a 62-year-old, divorced woman who was considering a reconciliation with her ex-husband, even after years of unhappiness inside their marriage. The situation was further complicated by the fact that he was engaged to another woman. Find out how the letter-writer and her ex-husband decided to proceed.

item.title: a16z Podcast: Sleep!
item.description: Sleep, productivity, and creatively are intimately linked, for better and for worse. And "we are living under a collective delusion that burnout is the way to succeed," observes Arianna Huffington, author of The Sleep Revolution.
item.itunes:author: Amazing Articles

item.description: Jim Kwik talks about how he went from almost failing out of school to being a speed reader and ending up imparting learning tactics to the likes of Will Smith, Richard Branson and Stan Lee.

item.title: Tim Ferriss: Tony Robbins - On Achievement Versus Fulfillment
item.description: For those of you that aren't familiar, Tony Robbins is the world's most famous performance coach. He's advised everyone from Bill Clinton to Mikhail Gorbachev to Serena Williams, and Leonardo DiCaprio to Oprah (who calls him "superhuman").

item.title: Recode Replay: Elon Musk, CEO, SpaceX and Tesla (Code Conference 2016)
item.description: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk talks with Recode's Kara Swisher and The Verge's Walt Mossberg about his plans to send a one-way rocket to Mars in 2018. He estimates colonists could start arriving on the Red Planet by 2025.

item.title: Politico Off Message: Tony Blair - Centrism may be dead
item.description: Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair sits down with Glenn Thrush in London to discuss the relationship between American and British politics, his close relationship with the Clintons, Brexit, and the danger of approaching politics with a closed-mind.
item.itunes:author: POLITICO
item.itunes:subtitle: Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair sits down with Glenn Thrush in London to discuss the relationship between American and British politics, his close relationship with the Clintons, Brexit, and the danger of approaching politics with a closed-mind.

item.title: Invisibilia: The Secret History of Thoughts
item.description: In "The Secret History of Thoughts," co-hosts Alix Spiegel and Lulu Miller ask the question, "Are my thoughts related to my inner wishes, do they reveal who I really am?" The answer can have profound consequences for your life.
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:subtitle: In "The Secret History of Thoughts," co-hosts Alix Spiegel and Lulu Miller ask the question, "Are my thoughts related to my inner wishes, do they reveal who I really am?" The answer can have profound consequences for your life.

item.title: Freakonomics Radio: Are You Ready for a Glorious Sunset?
item.description: The gist: we spend billions on end-of-life healthcare that doesn’t do much good. So what if a patient could forego the standard treatment and get a cash rebate instead?
item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio
item.itunes:subtitle: The gist: we spend billions on end-of-life healthcare that doesn’t do much good. So what if a patient could forego the standard treatment and get a cash rebate instead?

item.description: This episode is very special to me and features a verbal Jedi who never gets interviewed himself: Cal Fussman.
item.itunes:author: Tim Ferriss: Bestselling Author, Human Guinea Pig
item.itunes:subtitle: This episode is very special to me and features a verbal Jedi who never gets interviewed himself: Cal Fussman.

item.title: The Ezra Klein Show: Bill Gates on stopping climate change, building robots, and the best books he’s read
item.description: Bill Gates is one of those people for whom “needs no introduction” is actually true. The polymathic Microsoft founder now leads the world’s largest and most important private foundation, and he’s predicting that we’re on the cusp of the energy breakthrough that’s going to save the world. He also talks about the controversial idea that technological innovation is slowing down, assesses how close we are to true artificial intelligence, and explains why you really want to save being sick for 20 years from now.
item.itunes:author: Vox / Panoply
item.itunes:subtitle: Bill Gates on stopping climate change, building robots, and the best books he's read
